question: Hey, Jack, ever hear of a fellow called Willie Stark?
answer: No. Who'd he shoot?

question: Oh, county... uh... treasurer, or something like that.
answer: What's so special about him?

question: They say he's an honest man. What I want you to do is to hop into your car...
answer: Why, you promised me a vacation.

question: Well, that can wait.
answer: Yeah... but there's a... a girl I know.

question: Oh... Well, she can wait too.
answer: The question is... can I?

question: The answer is... get up there.
answer: Right. Oh... uh... what did you say his name was?

question: Who?
answer: The fellow's name.

question: Oh, the... uh... Stark... Willie Stark.
answer: Willie Stark... I found him in Kanoma City. A typical, hot, dusty, backwoods county seat.

question: ...to lie to them in order to line their own dirty pockets with the taxpayers' money. When have the citizens of Kanoma County ever witnessed a campaign like this? Why is the opposition so anxious to defeat me? Why have they used every dirty method known to make sure I'm not elected county treasurer? Well, I'll tell you why... ...Because they're afraid of the truth... and the truth is this. They're trying to steal your money. Yeah, I said steal. The county commissioners rejected the bid on the schoolhouse. Why? Well, they'll tell you their reason is the job will be done better. The county commissioners would have you believe that they're interested in public welfare. They're interested in welfare, sure. But it's their own. Let's look at the reason in the light of the facts and the figures. That brick factory is owned by one of the commissioners. That same brick factory uses convict labor.
answer: Sorry, Willie, you'll have to move on.

question: Why?
answer: City Ordinance Number One-Oh-Five

question: If you folks'll be so kind as to read these handbills, my boy will pass them out among you.
answer: There's an ordinance against that too.

question: Pass 'em out, Tom. Let him alone!
answer: Get that camera! Willie, you're under arrest.

question: Uh, they told me I could get my camera back here.
answer: Who told you that?

question: People. Can I?
answer: You the reporter that's been snoopin' around town?

question: Are you Tiny Duffy?
answer: What paper?

question: Chronicle.
answer: You sure come a long way to stick your nose into other people's business.

question: That's true... Only my boss on the paper can't see it that way.
answer: It ain't any of his business either.

question: Whose business is it?
answer: Them as is tendin' to it. County commissioners that the voters of Kanoma County elected to tend to their business and not take no buttin' in from nobody.

question: You a commissioner?
answer: Yeah. Name's Pillsbury. Dolph Pillsbury.

question: Who isn't a commissioner?
answer: He's the head man.

question: Then you're in a position to know where --
answer: He's in a position to know nothin'. And to say nothin'.

question: I thought you said he was head man?
answer: He uses my head.

question: He uses my head.
answer: Oh, Tiny, you're a card... Ain't he a card? Yeah, he's a card... Now, who thought up those city ordinances about arresting someone for making a speech?

question: Who's arrested? Nobody's been arrested. Hi, Willie.
answer: Hi, Willie.

question: Did you apologize to Willie?
answer: Yeah, I apologized to Willie.

question: Did you give him his handbills back?
answer: Yeah, I gave 'em back.

question: Give him back his flag and his bag and... give this man his camera.
answer: I'm going to be on that same street corner tomorrow, Mr. Duffy.

question: You go right ahead, Willie. We all believe in free speech. We got to... it's in the Constitution.
answer: My boy is out distributing those handbills now.

question: It's a free country, Willie. If you can convince the people to vote for you... you go right ahead.
answer: What did you want to see me about, Mr. Duffy?

question: I wanted you to meet a fella came all the way up from the state capital to meet you. A reporter. Wants to write you up... maybe put your picture in the paper.
answer: I'm happy to know you, sir.

question: He's a strong boy. Don't worry about him. He can take care of himself.
answer: How old is the boy?

question: Fifteen.
answer: How long have you been married?

question: And now you, Mrs. Stark?
answer: Oh, there isn't very much to tell about me.

question: How did you meet?
answer: I was teaching school and one day a pupil walked in. It was Willie. I couldn't have a grown man in the class and Willie wanted to learn so badly... so I married him.

question: Is that the only reason?
answer: Except that I loved him.

question: Two or three weeks. If that's all right with you.
answer: I'm sure your father would be --

question: Stepfather, Mother.
answer: Now, Jackie... here we all are. Floyd, Jackie, myself. To the best time we've ever had together.

question: I like what I'm doing, Mother.
answer: You do very well at it. I read your articles about this fellow... Willie Stark. Very convincing... Too convincing for my tastes.

question: A lot of people like them.
answer: A lot of people are fools. Articles like that shouldn't be permitted. They only tend to incite people.

question: Jack... Jack... you go back in and apologize.
answer: Apologize? I'd rather die.

question: I've got to live with him.
answer: Well, I don't. Neither do you. You don't love him, Mother. You never did.

question: Son, don't spoil anything now... He can help you.
answer: I can get along without him. You need this house. And the parties. And the cars and the clothes and the lies. I don't. It's the truth, Mother, face it. For once in your life, face it.

question: Anne, please... please make him understand.
answer: Anne, Burden's Landing is a place on the moon. It isn't real. It doesn't exist. It's me pretending I live on what I earn. It's my mother trying to keep herself young, and drinking herself old doing it. It's you and Adam living in this house as though your father were still alive. It's an old man like the Judge dreaming of the past... Anne, come away with me.

question: Anne, Burden's Landing is a place on the moon. It isn't real. It doesn't exist. It's me pretending I live on what I earn. It's my mother trying to keep herself young, and drinking herself old doing it. It's you and Adam living in this house as though your father were still alive. It's an old man like the Judge dreaming of the past... Anne, come away with me.
answer: And do what?

question: And live in a shack and eat red beans. Anne, what do you want me to do?
answer: Oh, Jack, Jack, you haven't been sure. You've gone from one thing to the other... a year at law school, and now this job as a reporter...

question: Are you afraid I can't make a living?
answer: Oh, no, Jack, it isn't that. I don't care about the money. It... it's just that I... I want you to be something.

question: What is it you want me to be?
answer: I don't know. It's just that I want you to be... to do... something important.

question: Like your father. All right. I'll run for governor. Anne, I'm sorry. I'm sorry I said that.
answer: All right, Jack. I'll go away with you. I'll do anything you want me to do.

question: Anne, I've wanted you to say that more than anything in the world, and now that you've said it... Anne, I guess you were right. I'm not sure of anything, including myself. I'm not sure I could live up to the... Anne, wait for me. Please wait for me.
answer: I'll wait for you.

question: Hello, Jack. Cut your vacation short, didn't you?
answer: Yeah.

question: By the way, Jack, the fellow you wrote the articles about... uh... Stark.
answer: Yeah?

question: He lost.
answer: Well, I guess that's the end of Willie Stark.

question: ...Measure of the damages is caused by...
answer: A breach...

question: A breach...
answer: Of an agreement...

question: Of an agreement...
answer: To sell personal property...

question: To sell... Oh, two years of this.
answer: Oh, go on, Willie, go on.

question: Do you mind if I sit with you, Sadie?
answer: Stand... sit...

question: Thanks... Tell me, what are you on this merry-go-round for?
answer: I take notes.

question: For whom?
answer: For those who pay me.

question: Which is.
answer: People.

question: Smart people.
answer: Oh, yeah. Anybody that pays me is smart.

question: You don't have to be smart to frame a guy like Willie Stark.
answer: No. No, brother, you don't.

question: It is a frame, isn't it?
answer: Why don't you give me a cigarette?

question: To split the vote and win the election for Harrison, huh?
answer: If you know, why do you ask?

question: I just want to make sure.
answer: Yeah.

question: Look, why don't you tell the boys back home to save their money. Willie couldn't steal a vote from... from Abe Lincoln in the Cradle of the Confederacy.
answer: I wish the poor... had enough sense to have somebody give him a good greasing for the beating he's going to get. 'Cause this way all he gets out of it is the ride. Hey, those speeches! Ain't they awful? Ain't they just plain awful? Question to you

question: Shut up yourself! Listen, Willie, try it on your feet this time.
answer: Oh, no. Wait a minute. My feet are killing me. Let me stay here, huh?

question: All right... Look, Willie, you tell 'em too much. Just tell 'em you're going to soak the fat boys and forget the rest of the tax stuff.
answer: That's what I say.

question: But it's the way you say it. Willie, make 'em cry. Make 'em laugh, make 'em mad, even mad at you. Stir 'em up and they'll love it and come back for more. But for heaven's sake don't try and improve their minds.
answer: A man don't have to be governor.

question: What?
answer: A man don't have to be governor.

question: Well, they haven't counted up the votes yet.
answer: Oh, I'm going to lose, Mr. Burden. I know that. Don't try and fool me. I'm not going to lie to you. I wanted it. I wanted it so badly I stayed up nights thinking about it. A man wants something so badly he gets mixed up in knowing what he wants. It's something inside of you. I would have made a good governor. Better than those other fellows.

question: Come in.
answer: A great governor.

question: What's up?
answer: Nothing... except Willie here has been saying as how he's not going to be governor.

question: So you told him.
answer: I don't tell anyone anything... I just listen.

question: Who told you?
answer: Told me what? Told me what?

question: That you're not going to be governor.
answer: Jack! Told me what?... Told me what?

question: All right! That you've been framed, you poor sap.
answer: Framed?

question: That's what they tell me.
answer: Here.

question: Hey, lay off that. You're not used to it.
answer: He's not used to a lot of things. Are you, Willie?

question: Why don't you lay off of him, Sadie?
answer: Are you, Willie? Are you? Are you... are you, are you, are you? Hi.

question: Well, things seem to have quieted down.
answer: Yeah, I quieted him down.

question: Yeah. How was he? Noisy?
answer: Oh, he reared some. He's been telling me all the things he's going to do. He's going to do big things, this fella. He's going to be President. He's going to kill people with his bare hands. I quieted him down... Hey! Who's Lucy?

question: His wife.
answer: He talks like she's his mammy... she's going to blow his nose for him.

question: Well, I'll take him from here on in. They're waiting for him at the barbecue.
answer: Yeah, well give me a receipt for the body and I'll be on my way.

question: ...So they told the hick... and he swallowed it. He looked in his heart and he thought in all humility how he'd like to try and change things. He was just a country boy who thought that even the plainest, poorest man can be governor if his fellow citizens find he's got the stuff for the job. Well, those fellows in the striped pants... they saw the hick and they took him in.
answer: Willie, what are you trying to do?

question: There he is! There's your Judas Iscariot. Look at him... lickspittle... nose- wiper.
answer: Play! Play!

question: Look at him!
answer: Play anything.

question: Look at him! Joe Harrison's dummy! Look at him!
answer: That's a lie!

question: Look at him!
answer: Go get him, boys... go get him.

question: No use going any further, Jack. We aren't printing them any more.
answer: I thought the Chronicle line was --

question: Divide and conquer? Stark is getting too big for his britches and the hicks are getting too smart. We're now supporting Harrison.
answer: How do you square that?

question: I work here.
answer: Well, I don't... not any more.

question: Jack, you fool.
answer: If you had any guts you'd print this...

question: I work here. I take orders.
answer: I know. You've got a wife and three kids and your boy goes to Princeton.

question: You won't find it easy to get another job.
answer: I'm too rich to work. We didn't do so good.

question: And a beer. I hear you got fired from the paper.
answer: You heard wrong, Willie. I quit.

question: You're smart. 'Cause before I'm through with that mob they're not going to have enough money left to pay the boy that cleans the spittoons.
answer: How do you feel, Willie?

question: I feel fine, fine. You see, Jack, I learned something.
answer: Yeah... what?

question: No. No, not yet. But I want to keep him around. He reminds me of something I never want to forget. Come on, come on, come on, come on. Are these the boys?
answer: These are the boys that can get the boys.

question: How many do you think we can get?
answer: Fifty.

question: How much?
answer: Five dollars a head.

question: Get a hundred... All right, go on, all of you. Blow. Blow, blow. You too, Duffy. Go on. Handbill distributors.
answer: If they all look like them I'd hate not to take one.

question: That's the object. Not like when they beat up my boy Tom.
answer: How is Tom?

question: Oh, he's fine. He starts college in the fall.
answer: Oh. And Lucy?

question: How much did they pay you on that newspaper?
answer: Three hundred dollars a month.

question: I could buy you cheap, couldn't I?
answer: For a bag of salt.

question: No. No, I don't play that way. I like you, boy. I always have. I'll tell you what I'll do. I'll give you four hundred dollars a month and traveling expenses.
answer: You throw money around like it was money.

question: Money?... I don't need money. People give me things.
answer: Why?

question: Because they believe in me.
answer: I was going home again. But this time it was different. Now I had a feeling that maybe the waiting was over... for me, and for Anne.

question: It's a far cry from where I come from... to this house. And standing here under the portrait of one of the greatest governors of this state, talking to you people... well, it's an honor I never thought I'd have.
answer: Are there any questions? Mr. McEvoy.

question: Yes. Yes, that's true. I have nothing to hide. I'll make a deal with the devil if it'll help me carry out my program. But believe me, there are no strings attached to those deals.
answer: You're sure about that?

question: Doc, Jack here has been telling me how you feel about things... how you'd like to see a new hospital built, a hospital that's the biggest and best that money can buy. You want those things, Doc, because, well, because you're a man who wants to do good. Now, I'd like to ask you a question.
answer: Shoot.

question: Do you know what good comes out of?
answer: You tell me, Mr. Stark.

question: Out of bad... that's what good comes out of. Because you can't make it out of anything else. You didn't know that, did you?
answer: No, I didn't... There's another question I'd like to ask you. You say there's only bad to start with and the good must come with the bad. Who's to determine what's good and what's bad?... You?

question: Why not?
answer: How?

question: What if it was his bribe! He swept the old gang out of office. What if they hollered like stuck pigs? He jammed through bill after bill and the people got what they wanted.
answer: I demand that this bill be passed. Nobody's going to tell me how to run this state.

question: He started to build the roads, the schools, the power dams, to change the face of the state from one end to the other... His methods? Politics is a dirty game... and he played it rough and dirty. Willie's little black book was a record of sin and corruption. And me, Jack Burden? I kept the book and added up the accounts. Clown, show-off, playboy, they yelled at him. Building football stadiums. Fiercely proud of his son who played in them.
answer: Oh, look at him go. He's going to be All-American.

question: You low-down, no-good redneck...
answer: What goes on here?

question: I'll kill him.
answer: Why, Sadie, I'm surprised at you.

question: I'll kill him. I hate all women. Was she pretty? Was she pretty?
answer: If I met her on the street I'd never recognize her.

question: Was she pretty?
answer: How should I know? I wasn't looking at her face... Look, if it's going to cause all this grief, why don't you let him go?

question: Let him go? I'll kill him. I'll drive him out of this state.
answer: Just because a guy's sitting with a couple of girls on his knees in public...

question: Public or private... I know him. How about what happened in Chicago? That girl on skates... and the time you both went to St. Louis... There's a new invention, you know, Photography and newsreels. Willie Stark in a nightclub... Willie Stark with a blonde.
answer: You could always bleach your hair.

question: I could also break every bone in his neck. After all I've done for him... Now he goes two-timing me.
answer: He's been two-timing Lucy. So there's another kind of arithmetic for what he's doing to you.

question: Lucy? If she had her way he'd be back in Kanoma City slopping the hogs right now. And he knows it. He knows what she'd do for him. She had her chance.
answer: You seem to think Lucy's on her way out, don't you?

question: He'll ditch her... Give him time.
answer: You ought to know. Hey, you got the wrong guy. I'm not the hero of this piece.

question: I don't care if she's dying. Sugar, get the car. Get him and bring him over here. Now, you know what you're supposed to do, don't you, Pillsbury? You're supposed to stay poor and take orders. Oh, there'll be some sweetening for you from time to time... but Duffy'll take care of that. Don't you go setting yourself up on your own again, do you understand that?
answer: Yes.

question: Louder, man. And say, I understand that.
answer: I understand that.

question: Give him a pen and some paper, Sadie. See who that is, Duffy. Oh, hello, Judge. Sit down. I'll be with you in just a couple of seconds. Now write what I tell you to write... Dear Governor Stark. I wish to resign as auditor due to ill health, to take effect as soon as you can relieve me. Respectfully yours. Did you sign it?
answer: No.

question: Well, sign it! Don't put any date on it. I can fill that in when I need it. Now bring it to me. Now get out.
answer: The papers have the story.

question: Yeah, I know.
answer: They're talking about impeachment proceedings.

question: Against who?
answer: This time, Pillsbury.

question: I got that "this time," Judge.
answer: How true is it?

question: What have we got on Hopkins, Jack? Hello, Jeff. About that Pillsbury business... Here's what I want you to do when it comes up in the legislature. Now, wait a minute, wait a minute. You listen to me. You got a mortgage coming due on that place of yours in about five weeks, haven't you? You'd like to get it renewed, wouldn't you? All right, Tiny'll talk to you in the morning. Get going, Tiny.
answer: You haven't answered my question. Why are you saving Pillsbury's hide?

question: I'm not a bit interested in Pillsbury's hide. It's something much more important than that. If the McMurphy boys get the notion they can get away with this, there's no telling where they'll stop.
answer: Or where you will... Pillsbury is guilty. As attorney general of this state, it's my job to prosecute.

question: Judge, you talk like Pillsbury was... was human. He isn't. He's a thing. You don't prosecute an adding machine if the spring goes busted and makes a mistake. You fix it. Well, I fixed him. I'm not a bit interested in Pillsbury. It's something much bigger than that.
answer: Yes, it is.

question: He's right because you want him to be right. Because you're afraid to admit you've made a mistake. Do it now before it's too late. I'm offering my resignation as attorney general. You'll have it in writing by messenger in the morning... dated.
answer: It took you a long time to make up your mind, Judge. A long time. What made you take such a long time?

question: I wasn't sure.
answer: And now you are? I'll tell you what you are. You're scared. You sat in that big easy chair of yours for thirty years and played at being a judge. Then all of a sudden I came along and put a bat in your hand, and I said, go ahead, Judge, start swinging. And you did. And you had a wonderful time. But now you're scared. You don't want to get your hands dirty. You want to pick up the marbles... but you don't want to get your hands dirty. Look at my whole program, Judge. How do you think I put that across?

question: I knew how, but I never knew why.
answer: You're not by any chance thinking of going over to McMurphy's boys, are you?

question: I'm through with politics.
answer: I'm happy to hear that. No hard feelings.

question: Goodbye, Governor. Are you coming with me, Jack? You're making a mistake.
answer: Do you think he means it when he says he's through with politics, Sadie?

question: All right. All right. Take it easy. I'll take your word for it. Sugar, take Miss Stanton home. When am I going to see you again? What's the matter, Anne?
answer: Please take me home now, Sugar Boy.

question: You've got to understand me.
answer: I understand you. It's myself I don't understand.

question: Do you think I like sneaking around corners any more than you do? But right now, with the Pillsbury business and with your uncle quitting... If I got a divorce...
answer: Maybe we'd better stop seeing each other.

question: No. No, we won't stop seeing each other, will we?
answer: No.

question: Because you believe in what I tell you.
answer: Because I believe what you tell me.

question: Ssshhh, easy.
answer: What if I won't do it?

question: You know, some of this has rubbed off on you.
answer: What are you going to do? Have me shot?

question: No... no... but I'll have to get myself a new boy.
answer: I tell you there's nothing on the Judge.

question: Jack, there's something on everybody. Man is conceived in sin and born in corruption.
answer: It's a waste of time.

question: What's the matter, Jack? Are you afraid you might find something out?
answer: I kept saying to myself that Willie was wrong about the Judge. If there was anything left at Burden's Landing, it was honor. I had to believe that. Anne, I want to ask you a question. Was the Judge ever broke? Really broke?

question: I kept saying to myself that Willie was wrong about the Judge. If there was anything left at Burden's Landing, it was honor. I had to believe that. Anne, I want to ask you a question. Was the Judge ever broke? Really broke?
answer: Why do you want to know?

question: I don't want to know, but I've got to.
answer: Did he tell you --

question: Did who tell me?
answer: I don't know. I... how should I know if the Judge was ever broke?

question: Hello... Come on, Anne, take this food and start cooking. I'm hungry.
answer: Me, I'm on the thirsty side. Bring some glasses, Anne, quick.

question: It's been a long time since I played this thing. What do you say we wake up the ghosts, huh?
answer: Another glass, Anne, for a ghost.

question: Remember the last time I played this? You and Anne were dancing?
answer: Shall we dance?

question: Calmly. Go ahead, Jack. Why do you think he wants me?
answer: Because you're the best man for the job.

question: It could have nothing to do with my name being Stanton?
answer: It could have. Let's grant that.

question: That's your answer.
answer: No, it's not. If that were the only answer I wouldn't be with him any more. There's another side of it. I've learned something from him. You can't make an omelet without cracking eggs.

question: At what price?
answer: At any price.

question: Do you really believe that, Jack?
answer: I really believe that Stark wants to do good. You do too. It's a matter of method. Many times out of evil comes good. Well, pain is an evil. As a doctor you should know that.

question: Pain is an evil; it is not evil. It is not evil in itself. Stark is evil.
answer: The people of the state don't think so.

question: Will I find anything, Judge? Will I? I didn't find it all at once. It takes a long time to go through old courthouse records and musty deeds... a very long time. But it wasn't too hard for me. I was well trained in research, especially this kind. I found what I didn't want to find. Have some photostat copies made of these. I'll be back tomorrow for them. Who is it? Wait a minute. All right, come in.
answer: Phew! Awful lot of smoke. Awful lot of whisky. You sober?

question: Stone.
answer: I'll have one with you. What are you hiding out for?

question: I'm not. I've been sleeping.
answer: For four days? You've been back in town for four days.

question: Willie knows everything.
answer: Willie's worried about his boy.

question: Willie's boy is worried about Willie's boy.
answer: Well, why don't you put something on the phonograph -- a low-down, mean blues. Play it over and over again until you're sick of it. Then crack it and go back to work. I do it all the time.

question: That's not my problem.
answer: No, it isn't your problem. I'll wait for you if you want to powder your nose.

question: I'll be with you in a minute.
answer: Hmmm. Yeah, I can see it. I've got to look in the mirror to be able to see it. Soft, white skin... not like mine. I had smallpox when I was a kid. Where I lived it seemed nearly all the kids had smallpox... It leaves your face hard. Then she's got poise. Look at the way she holds her head... at just the right angle. That takes training. That takes years of training... I see what Willie sees. Willie's got big ideas, Jack.

question: What do you mean?
answer: A girl like that could be a governor's wife. Or even a President's.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: He ditched Lucy, he ditched me, and he'll ditch you.

question: Answer me!
answer: He'll ditch everybody in the whole world because that's what Willie wants. Nobody in the world but him.

question: What are you talking about?
answer: You and your high-tone friends. What do they know? What do they know about anything? Why did you have to mix her in?

question: You're crazy, Sadie. You're out of your mind.
answer: Am I? Well, why don't you go down and ask her. Or ask him. Ask Willie.

question: Shut up!
answer: Go ahead, ask him.

question: Shut up!
answer: Ask him! Ow-oo... oh... oh.

question: He's off today.
answer: It's only practice. He'll be all right tomorrow... You been gone a long time, Jack.

question: Yeah. I figured if you needed me you'd yell.
answer: Why'd you lay around the hotel?

question: Thinking.
answer: About what?

question: Things.
answer: What did you find on the Judge?

question: Nothing.
answer: You sure you didn't find anything on the Judge?

question: Yeah, I'm sure.
answer: You're going to keep trying, aren't you?

question: If you want me to.
answer: I want you to. There's something else I want you to do too.

question: What? Bucket boy? Towel slinger? What?
answer: What's eating you, Jack?

question: What else do you want me to do?
answer: If you've got something on your mind, boy, spit it out. We've been together too long to play games.

question: What do you want me to do?
answer: I hear your pal Adam Stanton turned down the job as director of the hospital. That's bad. Especially at a time like this.

question: Oh? How did you hear it?
answer: Why? What difference does it make?

question: I just wanted to know.
answer: I heard it around.

question: How did you hear he turned it down, Willie?
answer: I'll be right back, Jack. I want to see what's happening here.

question: I'll be right back, Jack. I want to see what's happening here.
answer: I'm going to do it the way I want to do it.

question: Tom, come here. What's going on here?
answer: It doesn't make any difference to me either way... whether I play or not.

question: Well, it does to me. What do you want him to do? Tom, you're going to have to obey the rules. Do you hear me? You're going to obey the rules.
answer: I put 'em across, don't I? Every Saturday I put 'em across and I can still do it, drunk or sober. That's all you want, isn't it... for me to put 'em across so you can big-shot it around? Isn't that all you want?

question: Go on upstairs, Lucy. I have some business I want to talk over with Mr. Hale.
answer: What I've got to say anybody can listen to... Where's your boy?

question: Now... now, don't get excited. Get me another drink, Sugar.
answer: My daughter may die.

question: She's not going to die. She'll get the best medical attention there is. No expense will be spared.
answer: Where's your boy?

question: Lucy! You care for a drink?
answer: No thanks.

question: Accidents will happen, you know.
answer: Accidents? Your boy was drunk.

question: I saw the police report. There... there was nothing about drunkenness on the police report.
answer: Whose police and whose report? I say the boy was drunk. And I know it. Right here before your father... I want you --

question: Mr. Hale --
answer: Tom, the doctor says you need rest, boy.

question: I don't want you to try to cover up for me. I was wrong... that's all there is to it.
answer: You don't know what you're talking about. I saw the police report --

question: I don't care what the police report says. I was driving and I was drunk. It's all my fault. Anything you want to do to me, you can do. Whatever you want me to do, I'll do.
answer: Nobody has to do anything. Stop worrying. I'll take care of everything.

question: I don't want you to take care of anything.
answer: Tom, go on upstairs and get some rest, boy. Go on... go on... go on. Sugar, help him... Mr. Hale, come on over and sit down. You sure you wouldn't care for a drink, Mr. Hale? Hey, Tiny, go home. Go on, out of here... out of here. Go on. What business did you say you were in?

question: Tom, go on upstairs and get some rest, boy. Go on... go on... go on. Sugar, help him... Mr. Hale, come on over and sit down. You sure you wouldn't care for a drink, Mr. Hale? Hey, Tiny, go home. Go on, out of here... out of here. Go on. What business did you say you were in?
answer: I didn't say.

question: What business are you in?
answer: Trucking business.

question: Trucking business. Trucks run on state roads. If a man in the trucking business had a contract with the state, a big one, that would be pretty good, wouldn't it? Go on, Jack. Tell him what would happen. Go on, tell him.
answer: You're trying to bribe me, aren't you?

question: No, no. No, I'm not trying to bribe you. I'm... I'm only talking things over with you, that's all.
answer: You're pretty good at talking. I remember when you first started talking. A place called Upton. You did a lot of talking then and the things you said made sense, to me and a lot of other people. I believed in you... I followed you... and I fought for you. Well, the words are still good. But you're not. And I don't believe you ever were.

question: Get that man out of here! Come on, get him out of here. They're booing you.
answer: Ever since the accident, my head...

question: The doctor said it was nothing.
answer: Get dizzy... can't see... dizzy...

question: You're scared... plain scared.
answer: Get out of here!

question: I'm the one that made him play. I sent him in.
answer: Sit down, Willie. Please sit down.

question: I sent him in.
answer: What difference does that make now?

question: That's up to Governor Stark. He wanted another doctor... a specialist. I sent for one.
answer: How bad is it really, doctor?

question: He's unconscious... and paralyzed.
answer: Has he got a chance?

question: To live? Yes.
answer: What do you mean?

question: Even if the operation's successful -- that is, if he lives -- I think he'll be paralyzed for life.
answer: You'll do everything you can, won't you? Anything between you and me.. that won't count, will it? It doesn't have to. Look, doc, anything you want in the world you just ask for it and you got it. Go on, doc... ask for it.

question: How much does the doc know?
answer: About what?

question: Oh, you know what I'm talking about.
answer: About what?

question: About Anne and me.
answer: He doesn't know a thing... not a thing.

question: He doesn't know a thing... not a thing.
answer: Jack, how is he?

question: The boy?
answer: Yes.

question: He'll live.
answer: Oh, thank God. How is --

question: Willie?
answer: He blames himself, doesn't he?

question: He'll find someone else to blame in a few days.
answer: Oh, I tried to call here at the hospital, but I just...

question: Anne... Anne, why did you do it?
answer: He wasn't like anybody I ever knew before.

question: You mean he wasn't like me.
answer: He wasn't like anybody I ever knew before. I love him, I guess. I guess that's the reason.

question: Everybody loves him.
answer: He wants to marry me.

question: Are you going to?
answer: Not now. It would hurt him. A divorce would hurt his career.

question: His career!
answer: Jack... Jack, what are you going to do? You can't leave him now. He needs you now more than he ever did before.

question: What Willie needs, Willie's got.
answer: You don't know him. You've known him all these years and you don't really know him at all.

question: What about Adam?
answer: Adam?

question: Right over there, that's going to be the main building... fifteen stories high, like on the model. Over there, that's the laboratory. Finest technical equipment in the world.
answer: What are you trying to convince me of? I've taken the job.

question: Why?
answer: My reasons are my own. Why are you building a hospital?

question: To do some good for the people of the state.
answer: And get some votes.

question: Oh, there are lots of ways to get votes.
answer: Yes, I know... I won't stand for any interference.

question: I won't interfere. I may fire you, but I won't interfere.
answer: If that's a threat, you're wasting your time. You know what I think of your administration.

question: Take care of yourself, Pappy. Oh, uh... how do you like the new radio I got you? You know how it works? You can get police calls on it. Come here, come here... I'll show you. This one for police calls up here. All right, go ahead, go ahead.
answer: We interrupt this program to bring you a special announcement. This afternoon, the body of Richard Hale, father of the girl who died in the automobile accident involving the governor's son, was found. A medical examination revealed he was beaten to death. The ugly charge of "official murder" has been hurled at the administration by a coalition of Stark's opponents, led by Judge Stanton, lately an outspoken critic of the administration.

question: Your friend, the Judge.
answer: Thus an almost forgotten incident provided the spark that might set off the explosion needed to rock Willie Stark out of power. The latest report is that impeachment proceedings may be instituted...

question: I'm going back to the capital and get hold of Duffy.
answer: You stay right here, Sadie.

question: Somebody's got to go back to the capital. I'll go in the other car.
answer: All right, then tell Duffy not to do anything or say anything until I get there.

question: Leave him alone. How many scrapes have I gotten him out of? How many girls?
answer: Willie, stop.

question: It's not him they're after. It's me. How many halfwitted apes do you think I'm going to have to pay to square this one? What do you think this is going to cost me?
answer: What do you think it cost him?

question: A man builds for his son. That's all he builds for.
answer: Willie! Tom... Tom.

question: Give me a drink, Jack. She'll go. What's the score?
answer: They're lined up against you solid. They had a meeting.

question: How do you know? Were you there?
answer: Me? What would I be doing there?

question: We need twenty.
answer: We might be able to dig up a few more.

question: Yeah. Do you know how?
answer: No.

question: Oh, Jack. Come here. What have you got in your black book about that old friend of yours?
answer: Who do you mean?

question: You know who I'm talking about... your old friend, the Judge.
answer: If and when you need it.

question: If and when? I need it right now. He's got four senators wrapped up in his hip pocket. Come on, come on, boy... what have you got?
answer: I'm going to give him a break. If he can prove it isn't true, I won't spill it.

question: I ought to bust you, Jack.
answer: I promised two people I'd do it this way.

question: Who are they?
answer: Myself... and someone else. It doesn't matter who. I'm going to give him a break.

question: All right, give him a break. But if you got the facts, you got the facts. The truth is sufficient... just like it says in the Bible.
answer: That's the way it's going to be.

question: All right, boy... I'll trust you. Where are you going?
answer: I'll be around.

question: Are you sure?
answer: The chips were down, and Willie knew it. He was fighting for his life. He roared across the state making one speech after another. And all of them added up to the same thing... "It's not me they're after, it's you!" Willie hollered foul. Willie knew if you hollered long enough, hard enough, and loud enough, people begin to believe you. Just in case they didn't, he organized spontaneous demonstrations.

question: Tell the boys to get the hicks out. Bring 'em in from the sticks, empty the pool halls. Turn 'em out. Turn the yokels out.
answer: In case anyone hollered back, he organized spontaneous slugging. Willie pulled every trick he ever knew -- and added a few more. Hey, Sugar! You'll never live to be impeached!

question: Boy, I'll live to be President... I've got fourteen senators to vote against impeachment. If I win, you're out of politics.
answer: And always the trail led to one place... Burden's Landing... and the Judge.

question: You sure you don't want me to go in with you?
answer: I'm sure.

question: Well, hurry it up, boy. We've got places to go.
answer: Judge, I beg you, as a favor to yourself, to me... call up, release your votes.

question: Is it true, Judge, that you're behind the impeachment proceedings?
answer: Yes, it's true.

question: I wanted to hear you say it with your own silver tongue.
answer: Well, you've heard it. If that's all you came to hear you could have saved yourself a trip.

question: Are you kidding? Did you show it to him, or didn't you?
answer: Show me what?

question: That's what I figured. Let's get down to cases, Judge. Do you remember a man with the name of Littlepaugh? Remember the Fortune Electric Company?
answer: Of course. I was their counsel for over ten years.

question: You have tender sensibilities for a hatchet man. Good night, gentlemen.
answer: How about my answer?

question: You'll have it in the morning.
answer: I want it tonight.

question: Aw, you don't mean that, boy.
answer: What are you doing here?

question: It's all right, doc. Just here to discuss some politics with the Judge.
answer: Oh, I see. Well, good night.

question: Answer me. Did you give --
answer: Aren't you going back with him?

question: No.
answer: Why not? You belong with him. Jack, how could you have done it? When Anne brought me those papers she told me you promised not to tell Stark until...

question: Yeah. I know. Well, I kept my promise.
answer: Anne? Anne?

question: Come in. The door's open.
answer: Jack...

question: What do you want? No, I want to see you cry. Stop it!
answer: I called you. All afternoon I've been calling you.

question: I know. I was here.
answer: You've got to tell Adam. You've got to see him.

question: Tell him what?
answer: He knows about me and...

question: About you and Willie?
answer: I tried to explain to him. I... I tried to explain to him that it wasn't the way he thought it was.

question: How was it, Anne? You tell me.
answer: He hit me, Jack. My own brother... he hit me.

question: Your brother is an old-fashioned man. He believes in his sister's honor. Me, I'm a modern man. The twentieth-century type. I run.
answer: I'm frightened, Jack.

question: For who? Your brother, or Willie?
answer: We're through.

question: Who's through with who?
answer: He called me this afternoon. He's going back to Lucy. He said it was better that way.

question: Better for who? Him.
answer: Both of us.

question: Did he tell you that too when he asked you to betray the Judge? At least I walked out on him.
answer: Oh Jack... help me, please, please. Adam's all I've got left now. Oh, Jack, if you ever loved me...

question: If I ever loved you. I'll go find Adam.
answer: Where do you think you're going? Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't recognize you.

question: Do you know who Dr. Stanton is?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Did he try to come through here today?
answer: Haven't seen him, sir.

question: Well, can you check the other entrances?
answer: If you care to come inside and wait, Mr. Burden, we can find you a seat.

question: No, thanks. I'll wait out here. If Dr. Stanton shows up, let me know. Pass the word along to the boys, will you?
answer: Yes sir.

question: Anne, Anne... Where are you going?
answer: I don't know. Leave me alone.

question: To do what?
answer: I don't care.

question: No, that's too easy.
answer: I don't know, I don't know, I don't know.

question: I do.
answer: Leave me alone, please.

question: No, no more.
answer: He's dead.

question: We're alive.
answer: My brother's dead.

question: We've got to go on living.
answer: How?
